name: Glycated Hemoglobin (HbA1c)
description: HbA1c measures average blood glucose levels over 2-3 months. It reflects metabolic health and is a key biomarker for chronic disease risk.

risk_interpretation.low: HbA1c below 5.7% indicates healthy glucose metabolism and lower chronic disease risk.
risk_interpretation.medium: HbA1c between 5.7-6.4% indicates metabolic dysfunction. Lifestyle modifications recommended.
risk_interpretation.high: HbA1c above 6.5% indicates significant metabolic stress. Associated with increased risk of cardiovascular, kidney, and neurological diseases.

clinical_significance: Elevated HbA1c is a strong predictor of multiple chronic diseases including cardiovascular disease, kidney disease, certain cancers, and cognitive decline. Every 1% increase is associated with 18% increased chronic disease risk.
interventions: Dietary changes, exercise, weight loss, medication as needed

name: Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Cholesterol
description: LDL cholesterol is often called 'bad cholesterol' because high levels lead to plaque buildup in arteries.

risk_interpretation.low: LDL below 100 mg/dL is optimal and associated with low cardiovascular risk.
risk_interpretation.medium: LDL 100-159 mg/dL indicates borderline to moderately elevated risk. Lifestyle changes recommended.
risk_interpretation.high: LDL above 160 mg/dL indicates high risk of heart attack and stroke. Statin therapy often indicated.

clinical_significance: LDL cholesterol is a primary target for cardiovascular disease prevention. Reducing LDL by 40 mg/dL reduces cardiovascular events by approximately 20%.
interventions: Statins, PCSK9 inhibitors, dietary changes, exercise, weight management

name: Body Mass Index (BMI)
description: BMI is a measure of body fat based on height and weight. It's used to screen for weight categories that may lead to health problems.

risk_interpretation.low: BMI 18.5-24.9 is considered normal weight with lowest chronic disease risk.
risk_interpretation.medium: BMI 25-29.9 indicates overweight status. Moderate increased risk of chronic diseases.
risk_interpretation.high: BMI above 30 indicates obesity. Significantly elevated risk of cardiovascular disease, metabolic disorders, certain cancers, and reduced longevity.

clinical_significance: Obesity is associated with chronic inflammation, metabolic dysfunction, and increased risk of multiple diseases. BMI above 30 significantly increases all-cause mortality risk.
interventions: Caloric restriction, exercise programs, behavioral therapy, GLP-1 agonists, bariatric surgery for severe obesity

name: Age
description: Age is a non-modifiable risk factor. Chronic disease risk increases with age due to cumulative exposure and biological aging.

risk_interpretation.low: Under 40 years: Lower baseline risk, but genetic and lifestyle factors still important.
risk_interpretation.medium: 40-60 years: Progressive increase in risk. Screening and prevention critical.
risk_interpretation.high: Over 60 years: Highest risk group. Regular monitoring and management essential.

clinical_significance: Age-related increase in disease risk reflects accumulated damage, cellular senescence, and reduced organ reserve. Risk doubles approximately every decade after age 40.
interventions: Regular screening, preventive care, healthy lifestyle maintenance, medication adherence

name: Polygenic Risk Score (PRS)
description: PRS aggregates the effects of many genetic variants to estimate inherited susceptibility to chronic diseases. It captures the cumulative effect of thousands of genetic markers.

risk_interpretation.low: PRS below -1.0 indicates below-average genetic predisposition. Lifestyle factors become more important.
risk_interpretation.medium: PRS between -1.0 and +1.0 indicates average genetic risk.
risk_interpretation.high: PRS above +1.0 indicates elevated genetic susceptibility. More aggressive prevention strategies may be warranted.

clinical_significance: High PRS identifies individuals who may benefit most from early screening and proactive risk management. Individuals in the top 10% of PRS may have 2-3x higher disease risk than average.
interventions: Enhanced screening protocols, early lifestyle interventions, consideration of preventive medications, genetic counseling

name: Smoking Status
description: Smoking is one of the most significant modifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease, cancer, and chronic lung disease.

risk_interpretation.non_smoker: Non-smokers have baseline risk. Avoid starting and limit secondhand smoke exposure.
risk_interpretation.current_smoker: Current smoking increases cardiovascular disease risk by 2-4 times and cancer risk significantly. Immediate cessation beneficial.

clinical_significance: Smoking causes endothelial dysfunction, accelerates atherosclerosis, and promotes thrombosis. Even light smoking (1-4 cigarettes/day) substantially increases risk. Quitting at any age provides benefits.
interventions: Nicotine replacement therapy, varenicline, bupropion, behavioral counseling, support groups

name: Biological Sex
description: Biological sex influences disease risk through hormonal, genetic, and physiological differences.

risk_interpretation.male: Males generally have higher cardiovascular disease risk at younger ages. Increased risk of early heart attacks.
risk_interpretation.female: Females have lower risk before menopause due to protective effects of estrogen. Risk increases post-menopause.

clinical_significance: Sex differences in disease presentation, progression, and treatment response require personalized approaches. Hormonal status particularly important in females.
interventions: Sex-specific screening guidelines, consideration of hormone therapy, tailored lifestyle recommendations
